text: I'm Kim Severson the Atlanta bureau
chief for the New York Times I recently
took a trip to Sapelo Island which is in
a very remote part of an otherwise
well-developed coast in the southeastern
United States
97% of the island is owned by the state
of Georgia and there's a lot of marine
research that goes on there the rest of
it is owned by a community of people who
call themselves ski cheese as Cornelia
Walker Bailey the islands unofficial
historian will tell you everyone here is
a descendant of a slave who was brought
to work on the rice plantation that once
covered the island we acquired the land
right after the Civil War the people who
bought the land from various white
landowners who had it before and they
bought it and kept it in the family and
pass it down from generation to
generation
now the beachy people are facing a new
threat and that is increased property
taxes the 50 or so people who live on
the island are the largest continuous
community out Geechee in the country and
this tax issue may be the thing that
sends them under everybody who lives in
McIntosh County which includes Sapelo
Island is facing a big tax hike in 2009
the state of Georgia froze property
taxes this year it got lifted and the
tax bills that resulted are a big shock
property owners who were used to paying
a couple hundred dollars a year in
property taxes now have to pay three or
four thousand dollars it's a 500 or 600
percent increase for some people this is
a poor community there's not a lot of
work here people are elderly paying the
bills is going to be tough the county's
argument is that property taxes on the
island have been artificially low tax
assessments are done by an Assessor who
looks at all the property in the county
and coastal land in the Southeast United
States is very valuable so the problem
is how do you preserve a culture that is
one of the most fragile cultures in the
United States well at the same time
being an administrator of a fair and
equitable County government we want to
be treated equally
come to that tax in there for you from
taxing you then give me good road
service after you gonna tax me then pick
up my garbage you're gonna text me then
give me street lights you want to tax me
then you provide water service sewage
service fire service and that sort of
stuff
you're not gonna preserve but provide me
that kind of stuff there's no tax three
point the people in Sapelo Island feel
like they don't get the services that
they should be getting for these
increased taxes unlike mainland McIntosh
County garbage isn't collected by a
garbage truck people have to bring it to
a dump the one long paved road they have
they call the Audubon everything else
are dirt roads for some people whose
mothers and grandfathers have lived on
that land they're now facing a real
burden
do they sell off parts of the land to
help pay the tax burden on the other
parts of the land so that their mom or
their grandmother will have a place to
live but if they do that it's gonna
drive all the property taxes up and
cause their neighbors and friends to
have higher tax bills there's no
clear-cut winner just about everybody's
had a tax increase has appealed the
county has not yet decided how it's
going to respond to those appeals
whether development pressures will take
over Sapelo Island or whether they'll be
able to continue their way of life as is
what's hanging in the balance
